segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ aññataro bhikkhu kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
segments.en: At one time one of the mendicants was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena so bhikkhu yaṃ sudaṃ pubbe ativelaṃ sajjhāyabahulo viharati so aparena samayena appossukko tuṇhībhūto saṅkasāyati.
segments.en: Now at that time that mendicant had previously been spending too much time in recitation. But some time later they adhered to passivity and silence.

segments.pli: Atha kho yā tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe adhivatthā devatā tassa bhikkhuno dhammaṃ asuṇantī yena so bhikkhu tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Not hearing the teaching, the deity haunting that forest approached that mendicant, and addressed them in verse:
“Mendicant, why don’t you recite passages of the teaching,
When you hear the teaching confidence grows;
and the reciter is praised in the present life.”
“I used to be enthusiastic about passages of the teaching,
so long as I’d not realized dispassion.
But then I realized dispassion, which the good call

segments.pli: Yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhaṃva sutaṃ mutaṃ vā;
segments.en: the laying to rest by completely understanding
whatever is seen, heard, and thought.”

sections.title: At one time one of the mendicants was staying…

suttaplex.blurb: When a mendicant gives up their habit of reciting the texts, a deity questions them. But it seems they have now found peace.
